title: Randomized, Double-blind, Parallel-group, Placebo-controlled, Dose Ranging Study of Piromelatine in Patients With Mild Dementia Due to Alzheimer's Disease
description_brief: This study is a Phase 2, randomized, placebo-controlled, dose-ranging study of piromelatine (5, 20, and 50 mg daily for 6 months) versus placebo to determine an effective dose based on efficacy (cognitive performance), safety, and tolerability in patients with mild dementia due to Alzheimer's Disease (AD).
description_detailed:
Patients with a documented history of mild dementia due to AD for at least 6 months, having a Mini-Mental State Examination (MMSE) score of 20 to 27 (inclusive) at Screening.

A score of 27 is allowed only if accompanied by a score of ≥ 12 in the Alzheimer's Disease Assessment Scale-Cognitive subscale (ADAS-cog) ADAS-cog11 portion of the ADAS-cog14 at screening, and a Clinical Dementia Rating Global Score (CDR-GS) of 0.5 or 1 will be recruited and further screened for eligibility. Caregiver commitment to the study is also necessary.

At Screening (Visit 1), patients will undergo neuropsychiatric assessments, psychometric testing, and general medical assessments (including medical history, pre-existing conditions, physical examination, vital signs, and ECG). If patients have not had brain imaging with findings consistent with the diagnosis of dementia due to AD in the last 12 months, a computed tomography (CT) or magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) scan will be obtained to rule out clinically significant comorbid pathologies.

Eligible patients will start a 2-week run-in period of placebo (single-blind), followed by 26 weeks of double-blind treatment comprising administration of piromelatine or placebo, for a total treatment duration of 28 weeks. During the double-blind period, patients will be enrolled in a 1.2:1:1:1 randomization ratio to the 4 trial arms (placebo \[1.2\], and the equal piromelatine treatment arms 5, 20, and 50 mg \[1:1:1\]).

Intermediate visits will be carried out at 4 weeks (Visit 3) and 13 weeks (Visit 4) after randomization. A follow-up phone call to elicit any safety concerns will be completed 2 weeks after the last dose of study medication. Patients who discontinue before Visit 5 (Week 26) will be brought back for a termination visit.

Assuming an effect size between the treatment dose and placebo of 0.35 over 26 weeks, a significant level (α) of 0.05, and power of 88%, a sample size of 143 patients for the placebo arm and 119 patients for each of the 3 piromelatine arms is calculated. Assuming a 50% screen failure rate and allowing for 15% patient withdrawal, 1150 patients should be screened to randomly assign 575 patients, of whom it is expected that 500 will complete the study.

Piromelatine (5, 20, and 50 mg tablets) and placebo will be administered orally, once daily after a meal, before habitual bedtime, preferably between 2100h and 2300h. Patients will be required to spend at least 2 hours a day exposed to daylight.

participantFlowModule.preAssignmentDetails: The first period of the study consisted of a run-in phase where all participants received Placebo, followed by a second period where participants were randomized to "Piromelatine 5mg", "Piromelatine 20mg", "Piromelatine 50mg", or "Placebo" Arm/Groups for the dose escalation phase.

groups.title: Experimental: Piromelatine 5 mg
groups.description: Run-In placebo (2 weeks), followed by 5 mg Piromelatine once daily (26 weeks)

groups.title: Experimental: Piromelatine 20 mg
groups.description: Run-In placebo (2 weeks), followed by 20 mg Piromelatine once daily (26 weeks).

groups.title: Experimental: Piromelatine 50 mg
groups.description: Run-In placebo (2 weeks), followed by 50 mg Piromelatine once daily (26 weeks).

groups.title: Placebo Comparator
groups.description: Run-In placebo (2 weeks), followed by Placebo control once daily (26 weeks).

baselineCharacteristicsModule.populationDescription:
Out of 371 patients randomized, 368 were included in the Safety Analysis Set (SS), 352 were in the Full Analysis Set (FAS), and 315 were in the Per Protocol Set (PPS).

Out of 368 patients included in the SS, 16 were not included in the FAS because they did not have efficacy data for the primary endpoint at baseline and at least 1 postbaseline measurement. Of the 352 patients included in the FAS, 37 patients were not included in the PPS because they experienced major protocol deviations.

categories.title: Native Hawaiian or Other Pacific Islander

outcomeMeasures.title: Computerized Neuropsychological Test Battery (cNTB) Z-Scores - Change From Baseline
outcomeMeasures.description:
The global composite score of the cNTB combines the International Shopping List Test (ISLT), One Card Learning (OCL), Identification (IDN), Detection (DET), One Back Card (OBK), Controlled Oral Word Association Test (COWAT), and the Categorical Fluency Test (CFT). For each test, a z-score relative to the study baseline is calculated.

The cNTB global composite score is the mean of all z-scores from the tests listed above.

The scale range is from -3 to 3. Zero Z-score means no cognitive change. A negative value means decline, while a positive value means improvement.

outcomeMeasures.title: Change From Baseline in Global Impression of Change (CGIC)
outcomeMeasures.description:
The Change From Baseline in Global Impression of Change (CGIC) rating is made on a 7-point Likert-type scale where the change from baseline is rated as marked improvement (1), moderate improvement (2), minimal improvement (3), no change (4), minimal worsening (5), moderate worsening (6), marked worsening (7).

Mean values at 13 and 26 weeks are relative to baseline.

outcomeMeasures.title: Alzheimer's Disease Cooperative Study/Activities of Daily Living Scale Adapted for MCI (Mild Cognitive Impairment) Patients (ADCS-MCI-ADL)
outcomeMeasures.description:
ADCS-MCI-ADL is an evaluation scale with information provided by an informant/caregiver to describe the functional impairment of patients with mild cognitive impairment (MCI).

The ADCS-ADL is a 23-item scale that includes 6 basic ADLs (BADLs) and 17 Instrumental Activities of Daily Living (IADLs) that provide a total score of 0-78, with a lower score indicating greater severity, meaning a worse outcome.

outcomeMeasures.title: Alzheimer's Disease Assessment Scale Cognitive Subscale (ADAS-cog14)
outcomeMeasures.description:
The ADAS was designed to measure the severity of the most important symptoms of AD. Its subscale, ADAS-cog, is the most popular cognitive testing instrument used in clinical trials, measuring the disturbances of memory, language, praxis, attention, and other cognitive abilities that are often referred to as the core symptoms of AD.

ADAS-cog14 comprises 14 items summed to a total score ranging from 0 to 70, with lower scores indicating less severe impairment.

outcomeMeasures.title: Safety and Tolerability - Blood Pressure (mmHg)
outcomeMeasures.description:
Systolic and Diastolic Blood Pressure is followed during the study, as safety and tolerability measures.

Changes in BP following treatment, leading to values out of the normal limits mean a worse outcome.

outcomeMeasures.title: Safety and Tolerability - Heart Rate (Bpm)
outcomeMeasures.description: Heart Rate within normal limits = 60-100 beats per minute (bpm) during the study means a good outcome in terms of safety.

outcomeMeasures.title: Safety and Tolerability - ECG Interval Results - QTcF (Msec)
outcomeMeasures.description: QT interval corrected for heart rate by Fridericia's cube root formula (QTcF). The QTc is considered normal at \< 450 msec in males, and \< 470 msec in females.

outcomeMeasures.title: Safety and Tolerability - Hematology
outcomeMeasures.description:
Hematology (GI/L).

1 gill (GI) = 0.118294118 liter (L). No major changes or shifts from baseline mean good safety and tolerability.

outcomeMeasures.title: Safety and Tolerability - Blood Chemistry (mmol/L)
outcomeMeasures.description: Blood Chemistry follow-up during the experiment. No major changes or shifts from baseline mean good safety and tolerability.

outcomeMeasures.title: NeuroPsychiatric Inventory (NPI) Total Score
outcomeMeasures.description:
The NPI scale consists of 12 domains that are rated for both frequency (range 1 to 4) and severity (range 1 to 3). A composite score for each domain is calculated (frequency × severity), and it ranges from 1 to 12.

For each item, there is a leading question. If the symptom is absent, then the frequency, severity, and distress scores are not completed. In this case, the score is 0 for the item. The sum of the composite scores yields the NPI total score (1-12).

A negative change in the score indicates an improvement from baseline (symptom reduction).

outcomeMeasures.title: Pittsburgh Sleep Quality Index (PSQI) - Global Component Score
outcomeMeasures.description:
PSQI is an effective instrument used to measure the quality and patterns of sleep in older adults.

It differentiates "poor" from "good" sleep by measuring 7 areas: subjective sleep quality, sleep latency, sleep duration, habitual sleep efficiency, sleep disturbances, use of sleeping medication, and daytime dysfunction over the last month.

PSQI includes seven components, each scored 0 (no difficulty) to 3 (severe difficulty). The component scores are summed to produce a global score (range 0 to 21). Higher scores indicate worse sleep quality.

adverseEventsModule.timeFrame: 28 weeks (2 weeks Run-In Phase + 26 weeks Dose Escalation Phase)
adverseEventsModule.description: The data presented includes adverse events from the Run-In Phase (2 weeks of placebo, intended to assess eligibility into the dose escalation study), and the Dose Escalation Phase (26 weeks of treatment with investigational drug versus placebo).

pointOfContact.title: Tali Nir, DVM, VP Clinical and Regulatory Affairs

explanation_target: Reason: The trial tests piromelatine, an oral melatonin/serotonin receptor agonist, in mild AD with primary efficacy measured as cognitive performance (computerized neuropsychological battery) over 6 months, indicating the aim is to improve cognition/sleep-related function rather than directly target amyloid or tau pathology. citeturn0search1turn0search0

Act: Key extracted details — Phase 2, randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled, dose-ranging (5, 20, 50 mg daily for 6 months) of piromelatine vs placebo; primary outcome is cognitive performance. Piromelatine is described in the literature as a melatonin and serotonin (5-HT) receptor agonist with hypnotic effects mediated via melatonin receptors and additional activity at 5-HT1A (preclinical and review sources). citeturn0search1turn0search8turn0search5

Reflect: Classification — piromelatine is a small-molecule neurotransmitter receptor agonist (not a biologic) and does not primarily target core AD pathology (amyloid or tau). Because the trial’s stated goal and primary endpoints focus on cognitive performance (and sleep/cognition interaction), the most appropriate category is 'cognitive enhancer'. Note: investigators have discussed sleep-driven mechanisms that could indirectly affect amyloid clearance, but that is an indirect hypothesized disease-modifying pathway rather than a direct anti-amyloid/tau mechanism — this supports keeping the classification as cognitive enhancer. citeturn0search0turn0search7
Web search sources supporting the above conclusions: ReCOGNITION trial registration and description (NCT02615002) confirming design and endpoints. citeturn0search1

Mechanism / pharmacology sources: preclinical and review literature describing piromelatine as a melatonin and serotonin receptor agonist (hypnotic via melatonin receptors, activity at 5-HT1A), and clinical summaries reporting the trial tested cognition and sleep endpoints. citeturn0search8turn0search5turn0search0
explanation_agent: Reason: The investigational drug piromelatine is a small-molecule agonist of melatonin (MT1/MT2) and serotonin (5-HT1A/5-HT1D) receptors and therefore acts at neurotransmitter receptor targets rather than directly on amyloid or tau pathology. citeturn0search1turn0search12

Act: Key extracted trial details — Phase 2, randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled, dose-ranging (5, 20, 50 mg once daily for 6 months) in mild Alzheimer’s disease with primary efficacy assessed as cognitive performance; the study is registered as NCT02615002 (ReCOGNITION). These design and endpoint details support that the intervention is intended as a cognitive/sleep-enhancing receptor-targeting therapy rather than an anti-amyloid/tau disease-modifying biologic. citeturn0search0turn0search6

Act (mechanism sources): Pharmacology summaries describe piromelatine (Neu‑P11) as an agonist at melatonin MT1/MT2 receptors and serotonin 5-HT1A/5-HT1D receptors (with additional low-affinity activity at other targets reported in some sources), consistent with classification under neurotransmitter receptors. citeturn0search1turn0search3

Reflect: Classification choice — D) Neurotransmitter Receptors. Rationale: the drug’s primary known molecular targets are neurotransmitter receptors (melatonin and serotonin receptors). Although the drug modulates sleep/circadian processes (an O) Circadian Rhythm consideration), the most specific CADRO mapping is to neurotransmitter receptors because the direct molecular targets are GPCR neurotransmitter receptors. This is not a multi-target biologic nor a diagnostic/non-therapeutic study, so 'D' is the best fit. citeturn0search1turn0search12

Web search results used: NCATS drug entry for piromelatine (mechanism summary). citeturn0search1; NCT02615002 trial registration / trial snapshot (design, phase, doses, endpoints). citeturn0search0; Wikipedia summary of piromelatine (mechanism and trial context). citeturn0search12; PubMed / preclinical reports describing melatonin-receptor actions and effects relevant to sleep/cognition. citeturn0search2
